tip: Dermatologist recommends SPF 30 as the minimum daily protection.
Wear broad spectrum sunscreens that offer protection from both UVA and UVB rays.
UV-A rays cause premature aging. UV-B rays cause sunburn and skin cancer.
Sun is most intense between between the hours of 10 A.M. and 4 P.M. Seek shade mid day.
Often we don’t apply enough sunscreen. Try reapplying 20 minutes later to compensate for the initial under-application.
Reapply sunscreen after a vigorous activities. Sunscreen is removed by swimming and excessive sweating.
When the UV Index is 9, you can get a sunburn in less than 15 minutes.
Even when the UV Index is 4, a sunburn is possible within 50 minutes.
Up to 80 percent of UV rays pass through clouds. A sunburn is possible on cloudy days.
Snow, water, and sand increase sun exposure by reflecting incoming UV rays. It's important to reapply sunscreen often.
Water resistant sunscreens must maintain their SPF after 40 minutes of water immersion, while VERY water resistant must maintain protection for 80 minutes.
The Shadow rule - look at your shadow and if it is shorter than your height this means that the sun’s UV rays are strong.
Keep a look out for sunscreens with oxybenzone and octinoxate, which are harmful to humans and coral reef.
All skin tones need sunscreen. Anyone, no matter their skin tone, can get skin cancer.
UV rays still penetrate the glass in your office and your car.
For a day outdoors, we recommend SPF 50 and don’t forget to reapply every two hours.
It only takes 5 minutes of sun exposure to get enough vitamin D for a day.
Check the sunscreen’s expiration date. Its shelf life is shorter if it has been exposed to high temperatures.
Sunglasses shield your eyes from UV rays. Look for a pair that blocks 99% or 100% of UVB and UVA rays.
Say no to tanning! There's no such thing as a safe tan, whether you're inside or outside.
Don’t forget to protect your lips, neck and ears with SPF, as these are common areas for skin cancer due to lack of protection.
Young babies should be kept out of the sun entirely. Use sunscreen on babies over 6 months of age.
